speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31 \mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81 \mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 675, 532, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 72, 544, 89]]<|/det|>
## Section A  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[298, 102, 700, 121]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the spaces provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 148, 99, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 149, 430, 168]]<|/det|>
State Newton's law of gravitation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 272, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 875, 307]]<|/det|>
A star and a planet are isolated in space. The planet orbits the star in a circular orbit of radius \(R\), as illustrated in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 317, 665, 545]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 545, 532, 564]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 584, 596]]<|/det|>
The angular speed of the planet about the star is \(\omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 592, 875, 626]]<|/det|>
By considering the circular motion of the planet about the star of mass \(M,\) show that \(\omega\) and \(R\) are related by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 637, 552, 656]]<|/det|>
\[R^{3}\omega^{2} = GM\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 669, 643, 688]]<|/det|>
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant. Explain your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 852, 875, 871]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 873, 108]]<|/det|>
The Earth orbits the Sun in a circular orbit of radius \(1.5 \times 10^{8} \text{km}\). The mass of the Sun is \(2.0 \times 10^{30} \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 103, 875, 138]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 149, 636, 168]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 195, 875, 230]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 335, 870, 355]]<|/det|>
The mean kinetic energy \(< E_{\mathrm{K}}>\) of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 368, 551, 389]]<|/det|>
\[< E_{\mathrm{K}}> = \frac{3}{2} kT\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 875, 420]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant and \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 875, 466]]<|/det|>
A cylinder contains 1.0 mol of an ideal gas. The gas is heated so that its temperature changes from 280 K to 460 K.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 478, 183, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 477, 732, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 661, 875, 680]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 85, 873, 120]]<|/det|>

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 828, 91]]<|/det|>
A particle has mass \(m\) and charge \(+q\) and is travelling with speed \(v\) through a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 875, 121]]<|/det|>
The initial direction of travel is parallel to the plane of two charged horizontal metal plates, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 128, 838, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 336, 532, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 875, 402]]<|/det|>
The uniform electric field between the plates has magnitude \(2.8 \times 10^{4} \text{V} \text{m}^{-1}\) and is zero outside the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 873, 416]]<|/det|>
The particle passes between the plates and emerges beyond them, as illustrated in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 429, 144, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 796, 448]]<|/det|>
Explain why the path of the particle in the electric field is not an arc of a circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 553, 144, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 553, 875, 603]]<|/det|>
A uniform magnetic field is now formed in the region between the metal plates. The magnetic field strength is adjusted so that the positively charged particle passes undeviated between the plates, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 612, 819, 816]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 817, 532, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 544, 92]]<|/det|>
By reference to the photoelectric effect, explain

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 180, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 102, 517, 121]]<|/det|>
what is meant by work function energy,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 78, 945, 121]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 225, 180, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 225, 875, 260]]<|/det|>
why, even when the incident light is monochromatic, the emitted electrons have a range of kinetic energy up to a maximum value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 330, 875, 349]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 364, 146, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 875, 414]]<|/det|>
Electromagnetic radiation of frequency \(f\) is incident on a metal surface. The variation with frequency \(f\) of the maximum kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) of electrons emitted from the surface is shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 752, 532, 771]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 443, 91]]<|/det|>
One possible nuclear fission reaction is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 100, 688, 126]]<|/det|>
\[^{235}_{92}\mathrm {U}+\mathrm {}^{1}_{0}\mathrm {n}\rightarrow ^{141}_{56}\mathrm {Ba}+\mathrm {}^{92}_{36}\mathrm {Kr}+\mathrm {}^{3}_{0}\mathrm {n}+\mathrm {energy.}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 638, 152]]<|/det|>
Barium-141 ( \(^{141}_{56}\) Ba) and krypton-92 ( \(^{92}_{36}\) Kr) are both \(\beta \)-emitters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 771, 167]]<|/det|>
Barium-141 has a half-life of 18 minutes and a decay constant of \(6.4 \times 10^{-4} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 460, 183]]<|/det|>
The half-life of krypton-92 is 3.0 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 197, 144, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 480, 215]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by decay constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 144, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 875, 355]]<|/det|>
A mass of \(1.2 \text{g}\) of uranium-235 undergoes this nuclear reaction in a very short time (a few nanoseconds).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 181, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 875, 400]]<|/det|>
Calculate the number of barium-141 nuclei that are present immediately after the reaction has been completed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 565, 876, 584]]<|/det|>
<form>number = ............................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 597, 181, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 875, 631]]<|/det|>
Using your answer in **(b)(i)**, calculate the total activity of the barium-141 and the krypton-92 a time of 1.0 hours after the fission reaction has taken place.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 797, 875, 816]]<|/det|>
<form>activity = ............................................. Bq [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 767, 92]]<|/det|>
The variation with time \(t\) of the input potential \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) is shown in Fig. 9.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 426, 876, 448]]<|/det|>
On the axes of Fig. 9.2, show the variation with time \(t\) of the output potential \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 444, 875, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 107, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) requires the use of a non-uniform magnetic field superimposed on a large uniform magnetic field.

<form>Examiner's Use</FORM>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 390, 137]]<|/det|>
State and explain the purpose of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 150, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 425, 168]]<|/det|>
the large uniform magnetic field,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 303, 875, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 148, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
the non-uniform magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 488, 875, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
State two reasons why frequencies in the gigahertz (GHz) range are used in satellite communication.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[898, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 873, 160]]<|/det|>
1. ..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 180, 173, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 227, 875, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 875, 306]]<|/det|>
In one particular satellite communication system, the frequency of the signal transmitted from Earth to the satellite (the up-link) is 6 GHz. The frequency of the signal transmitted back to Earth from the satellite (the down-link) is 4 GHz.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 712, 339]]<|/det|>
Explain why the two signals are transmitted at different frequencies.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 603, 462]]<|/det|>
A signal transmitted from Earth has a power of 3.1 kW.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 705, 478]]<|/det|>
This signal, received by a satellite, has been attenuated by 185 dB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 489, 631, 508]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power of the signal received by the satellite.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 673, 875, 692]]<|/det|>
<form>power = ............................................ W [3]
